title: Accelerating Medical Innovation in Time for Baby Boomers
sub_head: Just as Darpa created the internet and GPS, ARPA-H could fund medical breakthroughs in cancer and Alzheimer’s.
body:
When a philanthropist as prominent in medical innovation as Michael Milken advocates for the creation of a government agency, we should take notice (“Covid Is the 21st Century’s Sputnik,” op-ed, July 28). The private sector will always be the main engine for innovation. But that engine needs a catalyst to fire initially. Ideally, the Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health (ARPA-H) could be that initiator—assuming it can avoid the bureaucratic pitfalls that plague more established government agencies.
Currently, ARPA-H is proposed as an independent agency within the National Institutes of Health. But federal law stipulates that the NIH can oversee no more than 27 independent institutes and centers, and ARPA-H would make 28. If it remains under the NIH’s purview, the NIH should roll the comparable National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences into the agency. Alternatively, ARPA-H could be established as an independent entity outside the NIH.
ARPA-H’s potential to accelerate the development of breakthrough medical technologies and place informed bets on high-risk, high-reward treatments could prove revolutionary, especially as the baby boomers age. Just as the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency improved Americans’ lives by creating the internet and GPS, ARPA-H could fund medical breakthroughs in cancer and Alzheimer’s that eventually make treatments accessible and affordable for all.
Mark Dornauer
Washington
